Name: The Road to Reality: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe

ReviewList.Text: A complete and encyclopedic view of modern physics. Not for casual reading as it is full of mathematical equations; but as the author says in the preface the maths can be safetly ignored while still making the book understandable with some efforts. Covers everything from Relativity, Quantum Physics to String Theory. Penrose also explains the maths required to understand the various concepts. In all a great book from the master who gave us 'The Emperors New Mind' and 'Shadows of the Mind'.

Besides Lisa Randall's excellent book Warped Passages, "The Road to Reality" by Roger Penrose is currently THE book to get in popular physics. Although I have to admit when I got my copy I was in for a surprise. I had seen the high sales rankings and was expecting typical Penrose fair, instead what I found was an ambitious effort that could be akin to a principia for the masses. Penrose basically has the book divided into two parts. In part I, he takes us on a tour of mathematics, devoting a chapter to almost every branch of the field. There are chapters on calculus, complex variables, fourier analysis, group theory, you name it. I find his writing style kind of tough going, his explanations are clear enough but something about it has made me want to take this book in small chunks. This is the only reason I don't give the book 5 stars. Anyway, he doesn't hold back, not only writing a popular book that includes the equations but even assigning little homework problems! Moving on, the second half of the book is devoted to physics. Like the math presentation, Penrose devotes chapters to every topic in physics, so you'll find quantum mechanics, relativity, cosmology, black holes and string theory all here, presented in exquisite detail. In the end I think if you are interested in string theory, cosmology, quantum theory and the like, then you should get the book. Just plan on taking your time to read it.

The product of his own search for the Road to Reality, this book is a masterpiece of completeness. Expecting the usual fair for the popular science book, I was pleasantly surprised to see that this book includes a surprising amount of mathematical detail. While this may put some readers off, those who put in the effort to read through it will come out with a deeper understanding of physics and cosmology than they had going in. After addressing the roots of science and basic mathematics discovered by the ancient Greeks, Penrose goes on a tour of mathematics. This includes topics such as basic real variable calculus, complex numbers, and Fourier series. Nice to see Fourier series tackled in a popular book. Penrose also covers symmetry groups, a fundamental concept in modern physics. The second half of the book switches gears from math to theoretical physics, again giving a whirlwind tour. Spacetime, relativty, mechanics, quantum theory, spin, entanglement, cosmology, measurement in quantum mechanics, string theory-its all here. The book is a thousand pages, so if you really want to get through it plan on devoting a fair amount of time. Some readers may be put off because he does not cut corners on mathematics, the way most popular physics books do. But I say its worth it and recommend that interested readers give it a try.

This book starts out as if it were aimed at the lay person and even makes efforts to explain points that require no introduction to a college graduate with a degree in math or science.  (Example: the author rhetorically asks how one can have a square root of a negative number.)  And yet, less than one-fifth of the way into the book, he proceeds from assuming you don't know what a complex number is to requiring understanding of Riemannian geometry.  The author attempts to provide more than mere nonmathematical philosophizing as some slimmer books have done, but the failure is that his presentation quickly outstrips understanding.  This brings us back full circle to accepting on faith what the undoubtedly brilliant author has to say, but now in the form of a tedious, 1000+ page tome.

The book was recommended to me by an economist friend with a love of all things mathematical.  He recommended it despite the fact that I am not a strong student of math or physics. I was pleasantly surprised!  Penrose has a way of making complex math and physic ideas relatively "easy" to understand.  In fact, I would go so far to say that his writing and illustrations are beautifully clear. I spent a lot of time reading the book and cursing my high school and college math teachers/professors for not being nearly as thorough and clear in their explanations of concepts as Penrose. Yes, it took me a while to get through 1000 pages or so of mathy/physics stuff, but the fact that I actually wanted to keep going at all is a testament to the clarity and genius of Mr. Penrose. This book is so worth it! The best substantive reading I have done in a while!

Roger Penrose should be knighted.  He conveys this involved material so well it's hard to put my appreciation into words.  I studied this stuff in college and boy, could I have used this book!  If you've ever been astounded at the power of mathematics, specifically complex mathematics, this book is for you.  It is a work to savor.  Penrose has been my intellectual hero since he wrote The Emperor's New Mind.  This book is truly a masterpiece.

Did you ever play a game with yourself as a small child, "I wish..."  --- I did and I got very serious about it.  I very quickly progressed through the stages of wishing for a million dollars.  By the time I was a teenager I used to wish that I could understand everything in the universe.  By the time I was an undergraduate student in college I used to wish I could be arrested, put in jail for a few years and just catch up enough to do justice to the courses I was taking "THAT" semester.  By the time I was finishing up my graduate degree I used to wish I could get all the Mathematicians and Physicists in one room and force them to behave themselves and write some content that would give the rest of us a clue.  Since graduate school I have spent many many hours reading popular accounts of the latest 'bandwagon-theories' of mathematics and physics and loving every bit of it.  My wish slowly evolved to the point where I wished I could stay aware and awake enough to appreciate the new stuff as it came out.  Well; folks like Roger Penrose in this book and Brian Green in his two books and even Robert Laughlin in his book about emergent phenomena have basically granted my wish.  I really fell in love with Brian Green's books and found myself constantly flipping to the back of the book and reading the end notes and saying to myself, "Wow, wouldn't it be great if someone could sort of flesh all this out without requiring the reader to have a PhD in physics and math."  I read Roger Penrose's book The Emperor's New Mind some years ago and it only made me wish for more.  I can only applaud the Physicists and Mathematicians of our age for writing these types of books.  And I must say if you have even an undergraduate degree in math, physics, or any other physical science where you enjoyed the math and physics courses you took then this book is for you.  And even if you do NOT have a degree in math or some physical science but enjoy reading the best of the best then this book is for you.  I hope everyone will enjoy it as much as I have.

This truly is an excellent guide to our current scientific knowledge qua math and physics. However, this book has not been distinguished clearly as the advanced read it is.  Rather, it has been marketed to the average pop-sci reader. Without a solid math background you will flounder while reading this book. One other concern I have is that Sir Roger expends little effort in thoroughly describing current concepts in string and M-theory, while focusing on his own twistor theory. While it's natural for a scientist and author to spend more time on his own ideas, it seems that a "complete guide" ought to address competing theories completely, especially when the competition has more support amongst physicists than does twistor theory at the time of writing.

Many reviewers are harping on the mathematical density of this book as the cause of its failure. But, although I couldn't comprehend 90% of the math, I needed this book to lay out for me just what mathematical abstractions the great thinkers were capable of summoning to apply to their observations of physical phenomena. The presentation of these theories in all their opaque gritty detail 1) vividly demonstrates the astonishing cultural phenomenon of an animal species that has come to understand its physical setting in the Universe and 2) concludes inescapably that those who have an understanding of these concepts have a different level of consciousness than the rest of us.  One important impression I came away with was an appreciation for the confidence of the physics community as they assert often counter intuitive ideas. They discover time after time mathematical ideas developed centuries ago are a perfect application for recently discovered physical phenomena so they can't help but believing in their work because of this apparent independent verification. A good example being the conjugate operation of a vector space being thought of in the early 1800's is a perfect fit for the conjugate variables of momentum and position of a particle in quantum theory. Or Lie algebra (1800's) having an indispensable application in space-time manifold surfaces. I had to read each chapter several times with frequent visits to Borders to reference the College Study Guides on Vector Spaces and Tensor Algebra. One thing I definitely learned from that was that this book was not made to be read several times. The pages of my volume have completely separated from the binding.

This monumental exploration of the fundamental mathematics for modern science breaks new ground for popular science texts, and does a superb job at giving a terrain survey of some recondite subjects. A prodigious number of topics are included in the text, from Riemanian manifolds and fiber bundles to tensors and differential geometry. Astonishing to see this material presented in a book for the general public. There is more than one way to do popular science and math. A great many students sandbank somewhere near a calculus course and never manage, mostly due to lack of time or occasion, to pursue the avenues this opens up, like an unused tool. But there is a great deal that can be studied profitably if the right literature existed for that purpose. Much of the material of this type is stoked away in specialized texts, and it is remarkable to see it recast for the general science reader. Such readers will hear of exotic yet not altogether difficult subject matter for the first time. Penrose's strategy is the right one here, and we can be glad he had the nerve to include technical details. The text reads well enough that one can even skip the formulae. Covering the immense ground of modern science is a permanent crisis of public information and needs new experiments in exposition. We can be grateful for this audacious venture.

I have been looking for this book all my life. This book has some very worthwhile very hard math concepts. But I have been brushing up on my math to keep up with this book and it is well worth it. For me I need to rename it "The long Road to Reality". Most books are read and put down but this is one of those few books that becomes a part of your life. You struggle with it and each advance is cause for private celebration.

As a physicist, I enjoy reading descriptive and mathematical overviews of current topics by respected researchers - their insights are often profound.  But in all the contemporary books on mathematical physics, quantum mechanics, relativity, and cosmology currently available, none is so comprehensive and profound as Penrose's work.  His writing style is very readable, so in spite of its rigour in parts, it is difficult to put down.  A real gem!

The Road to Reality covers a lot of the same ground you would find in standard mid-level undergraduate mathematical physics textbooks, but within the framework of what might be called a "popular science" format (though with a *lot* more focus on the math than is traditionally permitted in the genre). It provides an enticing glimpse into the mathematics behind modern physics in a manner accessible to virtually anyone interested enough in the topic to pick up the book. And, unlike many texts that attack physics from a mathematical standpoint, virtually every subject is tied back to physical applications, with clever examples and thought experiments throughout.

As an admirer of his previous books ( e.g. shadows of the mind ) I was very disappointed by this massive effort on Penrose's part to describe the physical universe.  As a dropout from the Phd. program in theoretical physics at Caltech I still try and keep up with the latest developments in theoretical physics particularly in regards to quantum field theory and string theory.  The problem with this book is if you aren't already familiar with the mathematics underlying much of modern physics the book is useless and if you are the book should have been only 200 pages long instead of 1050.  Basically I bought the book to get Penrose's views on string theory and the measurement problem in quantum mechanics but here other than some useful criticism he added little to his previous works.  Though the book is inexpensive I still feel a condensed version written for those who can really understand this book would have been more useful. For those who are not familiar with the mathematics and the physics presented here dont even think of learning it from this book - it will be impossible.

Penrose begins with introductions to interesting mathematics. Throughout, he has lots of tidbits that will make it interesting to those who thought they were already knowledgable. His cute pictrograph notations for doing math are fun. His non-mainstream notions about string theory, inflation, quantum mechanics are especially worthwhile. This may well become the sequel to Gamow's "One, two, three, infinity". Gamow's book got many in my generation excitied about physics and mathematics. Penrose's ambitious new book may do the same for future generations (especially those who already have a PhD in theoretical physics or math).
Excellent text on how the universe works.  Very Technical and difficult in places.  Good knowlege of Cosmology, Astrophysics, and Mathematics needed.

I'm an engineer not a scientist. My math skills allow me to understand most concepts, at least on an elementary level, but never rise to the level of full comprehension. Regardless, I enjoyed working through this book very much; enough that I have gone back after completing the book and pick up a section here or there for that second or third look at concepts that evolve as they become familiar. I highly recommend this to anyone that enjoys discovery and is not afraid of a little work to find it.

This is an amazing book. It has so much in it that I do not see how anyone could learn it all. It is encyclopedic. Even the elementary chapters are a pleasure to read, as Penrose has his own insights on the subject. Some of the later chapters are peppered with his views, which may or may not be the mainstream physics views. I have the paperback edition, as that has a lot of errors corrected.

The author seems very knowledgeable and has worked really hard for the book. However, the book is pretty much useless even for a college educated individual with average math knowledge. The author keeps repeating that he will try to keep math to minimum and use it only when he cannot avoid it. But 80% of this more than 1000 pages book is math, advanced and difficult math. Average reader would be better off reading a less technical book on the subject.

I put this book down after the third chapter. Its turgid prose and heavy mathematics made it a painful read. I consider myself reasonably intelligent and curious (I hold graduate degrees in English from a top universities and have decent math ability), but The Road to Reality left me frustrated and confused. I may give it another try, but I don't recommend it for the beginner.

Yes, it's very complete. It is also a book with enough pages to give examples, formula, background info on how things were wrought up by scientist of early twentieth century. This book is definitely a good buy. Penrose is an excellent educator and really explains.

Penrose gets slammed all over the place regarding this book, but the simple facts of the matter are he is an extremely prominent and accomplished genius. If you understand 1/1000 of the books contents you will be thrilled as I was. Jeez, fifteen dollars - you probably will spend more than that on BEER this weekend!
I've only made it through about a fifth on this book. But that fifth was worth the price all by itself. Slow reading but an incredible insight into math and physics.

There are many excellent reviews here, and because I'm neither a mathematician nor a physicist there is little I can add. But for those like me who are smart, curious, and patient and who are wondering whether to have a go at this book, I say go for it. By the time you have labored your way to the end, you'll find that you have absorbed far more than you expected. When Penrose is not doing math, his voice and his prose are crystal clear. If Penrose loses you, sometimes taking a look at, say, the Wikipedia article on a particular subject will catch you up. If gaining a better understanding of physics is a longterm goal for you, then this book is a valuable reference.

Penrose presents an excellent challenge to the reader in this great book. Not only does it look thick before you start, but as you flip through it, you'll undoubtedly see symbols and equations you've never heard of. Unlike most pop-sci books today, "The Road to Reality" was written for a more serious lay reader with real mathematical applications and theories. If you're looking for a book that will teach you something about the mathematics behind the modern scientific discoveries, you should get this book. 5 stars.

I love this book! After so many pop science tomes(Strings for Simpletons, etc), it was so fine to find a book that dumps it all on you and interconnects so many ideas and disciplines. I'll be reading parts of it for years, and reading physics texts to try to make out the more obscure sections and connections. And I think it's cool that he makes no bones about being a Platonist ("scratch a mathematician, find a mystic!"). I'm so glad he spent the time to put all these ideas together in one volume! WARNING, bachelor's degree in math or physics pretty much necessary.

This has got to be the best book about the modern understanding of physics and what led us to to it that I own. I purchased "The Road to Reality" used from this seller and it arrived to me on time and in perfect condition. I've seen these books new in bookstores that were not in as good condition as the one I recieved from this seller. Five stars all the way around.

This book, explains mathematics in a different way than any textbook has done before.  Penrose blended complicated formulas of mathematics and then explained how they even work in this world.  This is one of my all time favorite books.  If you want to think about Physics the way Stephen Hawking or Newton did, this book is the right book to get
Amazing scholarship. Truly one of the most valuable books ever published. Mathematically very intimidating though. I have a life goal to read and understand it before I die!

Although this is a very illuminating book (I gave it a 4-star rating), contrary to its claim in the preface, this is NOT for those whose math background is limited to a high school level. You need a firm grasp of advanced calculus, abstract modern algebra and topology to follow the brilliant logic of Roger Penrose in this enormous, encompassing work. If you do have this minimal background in math, this book will delight you. However there is one small criticism and that is on page 960 where Penrose dismisses Category Theory as 'abstract nonsense'. What seemed to have escaped the brilliant man is that Category Theory has become the 'language' of K-Theory, which the latter has become instrumental in the study of D-branes in String Theory. That Penrose fails to mention the very existence of K-theory in this book makes its sub-title, `A complete guide to the laws of the universe', incomplete.

I agree with Michael J. Edelman and Steve Sonance (these reviews). This book is HEAVY mathematically - very heavy. Further the mathematics, while often illuminating to someone with a PhD in mathematics, is explained in Penrose's idiosyncratic style - not always getting to the mathematical heart of the matter in a clear way. As a mathematician who reads popular accounts of physics I found this book to focus mainly on Penroses's own slant on physics. I would have given the book 1 star because of its density. However, there is nothing else like it, and persistent and patient reading almost always rewards. I am AMAZED that this is a popular book. Perhaps mathematical physics is the new religion?

Despite the previous work of Roger Penrose concerning my favourite topic (neuroscience, mind-brain issues, consciousness, etc.), this is the first book of his that I have read (not quite finished yet, not that fast !). I am quite impressed overall, wanting a well discussed introduction to some of the primary mathematics and physics that have led to our current time. This, Roger Penrose functionally provides, though at times some of his discussion could be clearer. He has made a sensible and successful effort to write at a number of different levels so that those with no mathematical background can read prose for content and ideas, and those with significant previous knowledge and ability can work on proofs of various arguments, etc. This is certainly a weighty set of chapters, and I cannot comment on the appropriateness of some of the latter chapters vis a vis current arguments and the positions held by other scientists, but definitely, this is one of the most significant and important books of its type to arrive on the scene and with some significant effort on the part of the reader, should repay hansomely!

One of the best histories of anything physically important that I have ever read. I ordered it in paperback to use it but I've now got a hardback copy as well. I did the same thing with the Feynman lectures. I mess up the paperback copies as I work with them and have the hardback copies for reference. A really great companion to these is Fundamentals of Physics (I bought the 8th extended edition) Jearl Walker (Halliday, Resnick and Walker). Dr. Walker now edits the book, I think. Penrose's The Road to Reality is well written and topics normally far from the understanding of most of us are well stated. Two years ago, this book alone started me on a journey that was only begun in 1965. The other books are essential to get at the rigor of solving problems. But Penrose tells you why it is important and how to approach the process of thinking.

The definitive popular exposition of modern physics. This magnum opus requires a dedicated reader, but the rewards are well worth it. Filled with Penrose's unique insights and geometric visualizations, this work is valuable to the seasoned physicist and untrained enthusiast alike. It is also happily written in highly readable prose. My own copy is filled with notes and underlining on nearly every page and took me nearly a year to finish. It is a tribute to the field and to the dedication and intellectual power of one of the world's greatest physicists.

I'm only about 100 pages into the book. So far, it's very interesting. My only complaint is that I don't find Professor Penrose's explanations of math very easy to follow. I'm not a mathematician, although I had a pretty good background in calculus, and I've never had any trouble with understanding math when it's clearly explained. For example, Penrose's explanation of complex numbers was a bit confusing at times. However, I read David Poole's appendix (in his Linear Algebra text) on the same subject and found it much easier to follow. This could be just a matter of personal learning style matching pedagogy, but Penrose, albeit undoubtedly brilliant, is not the best match for me as a teacher.

Not a leisure read if you're planning to follow it closely, but I've never felt a stronger urge to thank an author for writing a book. This is THE book that was desperately needed--one that didn't make use of metaphors to dumb down mathematical content in order to make it accessible to the layperson. The book certainly has its flaws with respect to how easy it is for an educated layperson to follow it without skipping minor details, but remains incomparable in it's depth and breadth.

The reader must possess a high degree of mathematical acumen to appreciate the work and must have super-human persistence to make meaningful headway in this book.  This is a heavy -weight.  It doesn't get any better.  Kudos. Sir Penrose!

I am retired from a career in science, background in chemistry.  I got this book to learn the current state of affairs about cosmetology.  I enjoyed the math review but really cherished to push into current theories.  Lots of ideas and insights.  Get it, you will not be disappointed.

Roger Penrose presents a vast panorama of modern knowledge. He starts with the mathematical instruments that cast light on the road to the elusive physical reality. These instruments allow appearance of singularities, which make the current understanding of the universe incomplete. We cannot know for sure what was the universe before the big bang and how it will evolve and end. These questions find amazingly elegant answers from the physicist Eugene Savov in his book Theory of Interaction. Savov considers space experiments and afterwards draws equations. I highly recommend these two basic books to everybody who is interested in the creation and the unfolding of the universe and in the application of mathematics to this great mystery.

This is a meaty read and is going to take the reader a good deal of time to tackle. Be prepared to stop and start several times and keep a dictionary nearby. You're gonna walk away knowing so much more than when you went in, though, so the time investment will be worth it.

This is a challenging book, even for self-described intellectuals.  It's critical to put in the time, slowly, in the first few chapters, stick with it, and see the benefits unfold in the later, rather elegant chapters where it all comes together -- literally.  While Penrose can be a bit strident at times, he makes a convincing and worthwhile case for his explanation of how the laws of nature interrelate and flow into somewhat very unexpected fields.  Not having read many (any) other books on theoretical physics, it's hard to compare this to other books in the genre.  But from a more philosophical viewpoint, it's an impressive effort to expound on current theory and can make even a hardened 19th century Western European old-school philosophy curmudgeon like myself to take pause and think things over.  Well worth the time and effort.

This is an extremely thorough book, but it goes through an entire undergraduate course in math in about two hundred pages.  It requires a lot of background to read.  If you do the problems, the book is easily a year long course in grad school.  The casual reader had best have a PhD in physics or math.  However, for me, the book explains a lot of the mysteries of modern physics in trying to unify quantum physics with general relativity.

This book is being presented by its publisher as a layman's guide.  It is not.  I would judge it to be at least at the college graduate level.  As far as the actual content, I would classify it as a cataloging of ideas without insight or point.  I never felt like I was drawn into a discussion that was going anywhere.
I think this book is very hard if attempting to be read cover to cover. It's better to read a few chapters, then use it as an encyclopedia of introductions - and for that, it's amazing.
Gives a good overview of modern physics.  However the explanations can be confusing.  The first third of the book is heavy in mathematics.  I haven't read further than that....yet.
Impossibly difficult, but ultimately a release from simplistic notions of a simple universe....Start in the middle, and read one page per day, or month, but keep going!

This book took some time to read! In my opinion, if you want to understand current work in physics, you need to have the basics under your belt. Roger Penrose starts with the basics and works all the way through at a very challenging pace. He introduces the necessary math in a very straight forward, easy to understand way in the first few chapters and they were fascinating! After that, it gets even better building on the very basics where he began. This is not one of those books that you can read in a weekend or on a long plane trip, so plan to take some time and enjoy this one. It will be well worth the effort.

After reading this, you realize the name should be "The Road to Realities" (plural). Not only does Penrose demonstrate the relativity of all things, but also the creation aspect inherent in choosing from an infinite number of possibilities on an infinite number of abstraction layers, each with a potential of spawning infinitely more if pursued. In the end, Penrose shows us how both, he created Spinors, and the universe as he knows it could not exist without them. Thus, he created the foundation of the universe? If there were only one reality, the answer would have to be yes.

I was advised of this book by a friend. It is a remarckable book indeed! I do not know of another book that can transport the novice to some understanding of contemporary physics! I do strongly recomend this book to novices really very interested in physics (the reading of it requires patiency). To the professional in physics I would like to say that Penrose allways surpreends us...
Basically a pure math book describing physics...Not the other way around
This is what it says. Reality!
Superb, if overwhelmingly meticulous.  This is a book for an entire winter.

The title explains it. I was hoping this book would be more like "The Elegant Universe" by Dr. Brian Greene. Not recommended for anyone who is not presently seeking an advanced degree in the hard sciences (beyond the Bachelor's degree) or already has an advanced degree, Masters or Ph.D in a hard science (Physics, Mathematics, or other Engineering fields).

Warning: This book does not avoid mathematics. It manages to cover physics up to the present by introducing extremely powerful mathetical tools. Penrose spends about 20 chapters on mathematics before getting to the physics. Not many chapters, considering that he covers everything from basic calc to modern differential geometry (most of mathematical presentation is focused on differential geometry and tensors). Unfortunately, if you have not (at the very least) completed a college level calculus course you will probably find this too difficult. The people who will gain the most from this book are probably those who have already seen much of this material, but have not put all the pieces together. The use of the word "guide" in the subtitle seems to suggest that Penrose was aiming in that direction. This is not a breezy pop-science book like so many others you have seen. I highly reccomend this book to college students who are approaching advanced physics. The chapters on tensor calculus are very good. Where else can you find an informal presentation of the lie derivative?  Other books that cover this material are: Shutz. Geometrical Methods of Mathematical Physics, Spivak. A Comprehensive Introduction to Differential Geometry Vol. 1.

As i just said, i enjoyed the book very much, and true i did not understand half of what the man said, but if you truely love physics i think you can get something out of this. Maybe im strange, but i enjoyed this book so much. One great thing about it was the fact of his view on string theory. Not often will one find such a view as he has on the subject and it has lead me to question my earlier views on the subject. Also, I had never heard of Twistor Theory before and now i see it has some value and that i may start to persue it in my college career along with the new versions of string theory with 4 deminsions that he spoke of.  Over all, people who give this book a bad rating, just are not seeing the book for what it is. And that is a general guide to the most important theories, one that may not be the most percise at every turn, nook and craney, but one that is a great 1045 page guide to things in general and help people see the elegance in the math involved in physics.

excellent general primer for Quantum Mechanics and modern physics. Penrose is writing at a level for the reader who is willing to do some work to understand a very complicated subject. A much more educational experience than the usual books on quantum mechanics for the general reader

Its about time someone wrote physics without dumming down the text with no references to the mathematics needed for a complete understanding.  I loved this book.  It made me brush up on my college mathematics and even take calculus.  I strongly recommend it. For all who search for the truth this is one important tome.

I love this densely packed, entirely informative book.  It gives a new level of understanding for those who enjoy reading about mathematics but who (like myself) have received no formal training in the field.  There is a handy "notations" section, which was great, but I could have used a glossary as well. Otherwise, a great book and one I'm very glad I bought.

The entropy of the universe part was by itself worth the time and money spent - just fascinating.  The rest of the book is very long and the mathematics is frequently above my level, and only little nuggets of insight  make it worthwhile.  The price was attractive and I'm glad to have it.

This is a very thick book.  I find the math somewhat difficult, however the book does have some gems in it, even if you have to slog through a lot to get at them.  Other reviewers say more and better things than I can.  I keep this at my desk, at work, and go at it, on lunch, for fun.

A book for mathematicians interested in physics; that is what I felt throughout reading this tome of knowledge.  And why shouldn't it be as it was written by the genius mathematician, Roger Penrose.  This is without a doubt a great perspective on physics; Penrose does not insult our intelligence, rather he challenges us greatly (and occasionally takes our lack of knowledge for granted). This is not an easy book to read but it is worthwhile journey into the universe through surprisingly elegant mathematical and physical theories.  You don't need a phD to read this (it wouldn't hurt of course!) but because each chapter is so dense with material, it is better to take breaks often and synthesize the information.  This is the universe in a nutshell and the content is superb. Nevertheless, I'd recommend "The Road to Reality" to ANYONE who wants to expand their mind and is willing to work for their knowledge.

Excellent book for those attempting to understand contemporary physics and elementary physics.  Penrose is user friendly in terms of mathematics and physics.  Highly readable and a good purchase for any library.
This is a very nice, if math filled, description of Quantum Mechanics.  It discusses all of the major issues, in considerable detail.  It took me a long time to digest, however I found it useful.

Obviously Penrose is a super mathematician.  The book is comprehensive and well organized, and the illustrations are very helpful.  The first 400 pages concern mathematics, the remaining 650 pages concern physics, both of the microcosmos and the macrocosmos.  The equations are very abstruse, with very few actual computations provided, and very little physical data are provided either.  As a theoretical physicist and systems/mechanical engineer, I felt obligated to read this work, which took about 10 days to complete.  It was worth the effort, because Penrose does critique the existing theories and, in particular, explains the conflict between General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics.  He clearly knows that a better theory would be desirable, but doesn't provide one; his own theory, Twistors, has no testable predictions. No one seems to be able to come up with a viable theory of "quantum gravity."  What's irritating to me about this work is that Penrose goes through practically every idea in modern theoretical physics--except for the one I've been working with since 1965:  the Reciprocal System of Dewey B. Larson.  There is no excuse any more for the physics community to keep ignoring this unified, general theory--which is precisely the kind of theory which Penrose says he wants.  The Reciprocal System does feature discrete space-time, which Penrose himself advocates.  But Penrose will not budge from General Relativity and curved space-time, though all the recent space observations show that the universe is Euclidean.  Larson's work and my papers are freely available on the Web; after you read Penrose's book, you might want to look at the Reciprocal System.  I do recommend Penrose's book to mathematical physicists as I do think that his critique of the current situation in modern physics is right on.  I just think he's ignoring the solution!

First, I must state my position in regards to mathematical physics: I am sixteen years old, and have spent the last year teaching myself euclidian geometry and calculus. I don't consider myself a layman, nor am I a degree holding physicist; perhaps this places me in the very faction of this books missed target audience. Let's begin with the first half of the book. The greatest fault of this book is that it gives only a superficial understanding of the mathematics involved in physics. As I've said, I've spent a year, and used five different texts in learning what Mr. Penrose condenses into a single chapter of 15-20 pages! And for this, what most other reviewers refer to as "the beauty of mathematics" is really only a perverse aesthetic of what mathematics really is. I truly cannot see how anyone could derive pleasure from reading this book, aside from it's necessary faults, it's DOWNRIGHT BORING! And this is from a person who has spent an entire hour reading and rereading a two page passage on a difficult theorem of integration. While reading G.H. Hardy's "A Course of Pure Mathematics", I could feel my brain buzzing as it elucidated the axioms of infinite series, while reading Mr. Penrose, my mind slipped into alpha waves! This book is terrific if you want to find yourself daydreaming half way through a passage you can't remember begining. To give you a for example, take this typical passage from chapter 8, "Holomorphic functions rest uncomfortably with the now usual notion of a function, which maps from a fixed domain to a definite target space; as we have seen, with analytical continuation, a holomorphic function has a mind of it's own." This is by far "THE" worst definition of a function that I've ever seen. I feel as if my knowledge of mathematics has been tainted by the pedantic nonsense like the above quotation. I haven't read any of Mr. Penrose's other books, but if this is any indication, I believe he should be tried as a heretic against reason. If you, like myself were left unsatiated by this book, go to the masters of the subject, Hardy, Gauss, Dedekind, Maxwell, don't settle for this travesty of what physics isn't.

In the first few hundred pages Roger Penrose sets the mathematical foundations of science. Afterwards he elegantly studies the application of mathematics in physics and cosmology. It consists of seeing first what is going on and then describing the found patterns of interaction in equations. This real road to mathematics of nature is followed by the physicist Eugene Savov.  He models the structure of reality from spacecraft observations and shows that the application of mathematics is fundamentally limited. The observer defined mathematical objects cannot completely follow the discovered self-defined structure of the real bodies. Naturally Penrose ends in incomplete, allowing appearance of infinities, picture of reality - big bang universe that now enters its recurrent crisis. Savov reveals in his book Theory of Interaction a complete and self-consistent firework universe in which the phenomenon of consciousness is born from the properties of found patterns of unifying interaction.

The road to reality is not found in this book. Penrose doesn't explain what reality is, not even mathematically. The book is a failure. Penrose Road seeks to lead us to the so-called ultimate equation that will unify the seemingly conflicting theories of modern physics. Once this equation is found, however, the question will still remain unanswered, namely, why is this equation at the end of the road?

Penrose considers the big bang and uses mathematics, which does not correspond to the nature of reality. There are deep problems with the big bang theory discussed in July 02 issue of New Scientist, reporting The First Crisis In Cosmology Conference - Moncao, Portugal, 23-25 June. One looking for the structure of reality can read Savov's Theory of Interaction the Simplest Explanation of Everything. Reality has self-similarly evolving structure. Its depth cannot be followed in the modern mathematical constructions, according to Eugene Savov, member of the organizing committee of this conference. Penrose's book left me with more confusion than new insights.  It makes a good read for purely mathematically inclined.  His ideas are far way from recent observations, which burst the foundations of big bang theory.

It is amazing: the reviews center on the quality of the mathematical/physics presentation (which I think is very high), and totally ignore the fact that this, like virtually all books written in this vein, is supremely naive about fundamental philosophical issues. What I mean, briefly, is this: the book is predicated on an unstated, rigidly held Cartesian dualism, and for dealing with fundamental questions that is a very suspect ground--an expression of what the philosopher Lawrence Cahoone calls "philosophical narcissism." For an antidote, I highly recommend Cahoone's "The Dilemma of Modernity" (SUNY, 1988), or, immodestly, my own "The Unboundaried Self: Putting the Person Back Into the View From Nowhere", published by Trafford (2005; Details at [...]).
